conversation.text: First, we meed to measure out the wholewheat flour. It's a one-to-one substitution.
evidence: Measure out wholewheat flour for your recipe.

conversation.text: OK, I'm using one kg. What's next?
You need to add two teaspoons of vital wheat gluten per cup of flour. There are 8 cups in 1 kg so you need 16 teaspoons of gluten.
evidence: Add two teaspoons of vital wheat gluten per cup flour.

conversation.text: OK, I have added the gluten. What should I do now?
You need to mix the ingredients together well. Does it look like regular flour after you mixed it?
Yes, it looks exactly like bread flour.
Now you need to add some water to the wet ingredients,
evidence: Add extra water to the wet ingredients.

conversation.text: So, don't add it water to the flour?
Right, don't add it directly to the flour.
evidence: To be clear, you'll want to add this water to the bowl where you're mixing the eggs, oil, milk, and so on

conversation.text: OK, I have added the water. What do I do now?
Just let the bread rise a little. It should be less than normal. Has it risen?
evidence: Let the bread rise less than normal.

conversation.text: OK, I hope your bread tastes good!
Thanks, I'm sure it will be great!

procedure.summary: Measure out wholewheat flour for your recipe.
procedure.description: The basic process for converting wholewheat flour to bread flour is basically the same as above. However, a few qualities of wholewheat flour make some minor differences necessary. To start, add the wheat flour to a mixing bowl. Again, this is a one-to-one substitution for the bread flour in your recipe. If your recipe calls for three cups of bread flour, start with three cups of wholewheat flour (and so on).

procedure.summary: Add two teaspoons of vital wheat gluten per cup flour.
procedure.description: Wholewheat flour contains a substance called bran which weakens the effects of gluten. This means that it's necessary to add more gluten artificially than you would with all-purpose flour. This scales proportionally in the same way as in the section above. For instance, if you have three cups of wholewheat flour, you would add six teaspoons of vital wheat gluten.

Sift the ingredients together in the mixing bowl. When they are well combined, the substance you have in the bowl will substitute well for bread flour. However, for the best possible results, a few more precautions are necessary. See the next steps.

procedure.summary: Add extra water to the wet ingredients.
procedure.description: The bran and protein content of wholewheat flour tend to make it slightly more absorbent than normal flour. To compensate, add a little extra to the wet ingredients you're using for your bread. About two and a half tablespoons of water per cup of wholewheat flour should be plenty. To be clear, you'll want to add this water to the bowl where you're mixing the eggs, oil, milk, and so on. Don't add it directly to the flour or it will incorporate unevenly.

procedure.summary: Let the bread rise less than normal.
procedure.description: When making bread, normally, you allow the dough to rise to about double its normal size. However, with wholewheat flour, you'll only want to allow it to rise to about 1 1/2 times its normal size. This is because wholewheat flour tends to make dough a little less flexible. If you let the dough rise all the way, it won't be able to support its full size and will "deflate" somewhat during baking.
